choices.text: The infant most likely has an H-type TEF
The infant most likely has proximal esophageal atresia with distal fistula
The infant likely has a previously undetected, associated finding of imperforate anus
The infant is unlikely to have gastroesophageal reflux

questions.text: An 8-month-old infant with recurrent pneumonia is diagnosed with tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF). Which of the following statements is correct?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical history of Recurrent pneumonia in an 8-month-old infant suggests a diagnosis of tracheoesophageal fistula - H type, due to frequent aspiration.

Tracheoesophageal Fistula:

  • Classic Presentation:
    • Neonatal period: Respiratory distress, choking/cyanosis during feeds, inability to pass NG tube.
    • Delayed Presentation (H-type TEF): Recurrent pneumonia, chronic cough, abdominal distension.
    • Usually Associated with Esophageal atresia. Associated defects include the VACTERL association:-
      • vertebral anomalies (70%)
      • anal atresia (imperforate anus) (50%)
      • cardiac anomalies (30%)
      • TEF (70%)
      • renal anomalies (50%)
      • limb anomalies (polydactyly
      • forearm defects
      • absent thumbs
      • syndactyly) (70%).
  • Clinical features:
    • History of polyhydramnios
    • Drooling, mucus and saliva bubbling from the nose and mouth
    • Recurrent pneumonia.
  • Diagnosis & Management:
    • Confirmation: Bronchoscopy or contrast esophagogram.
    • Treatment: Surgical ligation of fistula.

Incorrect options:
Proximal atresia + distal fistula (Option B): Presents neonatally as inability to feed with excessive salivation.
Imperforate anus (Option C): Presents neonatally with Inability to pass meconium and vomiting.
Gastroesophageal reflux (Option D): GERD is common post-TEF repair due to esophageal dysmotility.

questions.text: A 3-week-old male infant presents with projectile vomiting after feeds, visible gastric peristalsis, and a palpable "olive-shaped" mass in the epigastrium. Which metabolic derangement is most characteristic of this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical history of Projectile vomiting, visible peristalsis and characteristic olive-shaped palpable mass in the epigastrium suggests a diagnosis of Pyloric stenosis, which is frequently associated with Hypochloremic alkalosis.

Congenital Pyloric stenosis:

  • Pathophysiology:
    • Hypertrophy of pyloric smooth muscle → gastric outlet obstruction
    • Leads to projective non-bilious vomiting (classic symptom)
    • Typically presents at 3-6 weeks of age
  • Risk factors:
    • Postnatal Erythromycin Exposure:
      • Mechanism: Erythromycin acts as a motilin agonist → abnormal pyloric muscle contractions → hypertrophy.
      • Includes: Oral, IV, or topical erythromycin (e.g., for conjunctivitis prophylaxis).
    • Male Gender (M:F=4:1).
    • First-born infants.
    • Family history (↑ risk if parent had HPS).

Metabolic Derangement Mechanism:

  1. Vomiting of gastric contents → Loss of:
    • Hydrochloric acid (HCl) → Leads to:
      • Hypochloremia (low chloride)
      • Metabolic alkalosis (loss of H+ ions) (Options B, C, D ruled out)
    • Potassium → Results in Hypokalemia
  2. Renal Compensation Attempts:
    • Kidneys excrete bicarbonate (HCO3-) to correct alkalosis
    • But this requires exchanging with potassium (K+) → Worsens hypokalemia
    • Eventually leads to paradoxical aciduria (acidic urine despite systemic alkalosis)
  3. Unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia:
    • Seen in 5-10% of IHPS cases
    • Mechanism: It is theorised to be due to:-
      • Impaired hepatic vascular supply due to increased intra-abdominal pressure
      • Reduced caloric intake → ↓ hepatic UDP-glucuronyltransferase activity
      • Dehydration → Hemoconcentration
    • Resolves after Pyloromyotomy

Diagnosis:

  • Ultrasound: Gold standard (pyloric muscle thickness >4mm)
  • Blood Gas: Shows hypochloremic hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis
  • Electrolytes: Low K+, Low Cl-, Elevated HCO3-
  • Barium swallow: 'String' sign

Barium swallow: String sign:-

Management:

  1. Fluid Resuscitation: NS followed by 1/2 NS with 5% dextrose, KCl (after urine output established)
  2. Surgical: Pyloromyotomy (Ramstedt procedure)

Key Takeaways:

  • Classic triad: Projectile vomiting + Olive mass + Hypochloremic alkalosis
  • Always check electrolytes and blood gas preoperatively

questions.text: A 29-day-old boy presents with projectile vomiting, a palpable pyloric "olive," and visible peristaltic waves. Which of the following is a recognized risk factor for this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis:

  • Definition: Hypertrophy of the pyloric smooth muscle → gastric outlet obstruction.
  • Classic Presentation:
    • Age: 3-12 weeks (peak: 4-6 weeks).
    • Symptoms: Projectile nonbilious vomiting, hunger, dehydration.
    • Exam: Palpable "olive" mass (RUQ), visible peristaltic waves.

Risk Factors

  1. Postnatal Erythromycin Exposure (Option D):
    • Strongest modifiable risk factor (↑ risk 8-10×).
    • Mechanism: Erythromycin acts as a motilin agonist → abnormal pyloric muscle contractions → hypertrophy.
    • Includes: Oral, IV, or topical erythromycin (e.g., for conjunctivitis prophylaxis).
  2. Male Gender (Option C):
    • True association (M:F = 4:1) but not the best answer (question asks for recognized risk, not demographic).
  3. Other Risks:
    • First-born infants.
    • Family history (↑ risk if parent had HPS).

Diagnosis & Management

  • Ultrasound: Pyloric muscle thickness >4 mm, length >16 mm.
  • Treatment: Pyloromyotomy (Ramstedt procedure).

questions.text: You are called to evaluate a 1-day-old infant with vomiting after every feed. The vomiting is nonbilious, and the infant feeds eagerly. The mother had polyhydramnios during pregnancy. An abdominal radiograph shows a large, dilated stomach. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In the given clinical scenario, the Key Clinical Clues are

  • Timing: Symptoms begin day 1 of life (vs. pyloric stenosis at 3-6 weeks).
  • Vomiting:
    • Nonbilious (obstruction proximal to Ampulla of Vater).
    • Immediate post-feed (gastric outlet obstruction).
  • Polyhydramnios: Suggests proximal GI obstruction (impaired fetal swallowing).
  • X-ray abdomen: "Single bubble" sign (dilated stomach with no distal air).

This clinical history suggests a diagnosis of Pyloric atresia.

Pyloric Atresia:

  • It is characterised by 'Complete gastric outlet obstruction' at birth.
  • Clinical features:
    • Symptoms present from birth
    • Non-biliuos vomiting immediately on feeding
  • Associations:
    • Epidermolysis bullosa (30% of cases).
    • Other GI atresias (e.g., esophageal).
  • Diagnosis:
    • X-ray: Large stomach with no distal gas - 'single bubble' sign (also observed in Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis).
    • Barium swallow: Contrast fails to pass pylorus.
  • Management: Surgical repair (Pyloroplasty/Pyloric reconstruction).

Key Takeaways:

  • Day 1 nonbilious vomiting + polyhydramnios = Proximal obstruction (pyloric/duodenal).
  • "Single bubble" on X-ray is indicative of Pyloric atresia (vs. "Double bubble" in Duodenal atresia).

questions.text: A 11-year-old boy presents with weekly episodes of non-bloody, non-bilious vomiting preceded by substernal burning pain for 3 months. His BMI is at the 80th percentile. What is the next most appropriate step in management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given clinical history of frequent non-bloody, non-bilious vomiting and substernal/epigastric pain is suggestive of Gastro-Esophageal Reflux Disease (GERD), which is managed initially with PPI therapy, at least for 2 weeks.

Features:

  • Substernal burning pain (heartburn) + regurgitation/vomiting.
  • Non-bilious, non-bloody emesis with normal BMI (rules out obesity-related GERD).
  • Chronicity (>3 months) suggests non-functional

Management: Empirical PPI Trial:-

  • First-line for suspected GERD.
  • Drug examples: Omeprazole (1 mg/kg/day) or Esomeprazole.
  • Duration: 2-4 weeks (symptom resolution confirms diagnosis).

Incorrect options:

Referral to pediatric gastroenterology (Option A): Done in case of presence of 'Red flags' or PPI failure

Red Flags Requiring Referral:-

  • Failure to thrive
  • Hematemesis or dysphagia
  • Bilious vomiting

Upper GI contrast study (Option C): Done to rule out anatomical pathology, but not indicated during initial presentation.

Ondansetron as needed for nausea (Option D): Does not provide relief from chronic GERD.

Key Takeaways

  1. PPI trial is diagnostic and therapeutic for uncomplicated GERD.
  2. Avoid imaging unless alarm symptoms present.
  3. Lifestyle modifications: Avoid late meals, caffeine, and acidic foods.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a red flag sign for vomiting in a child?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Photophobia associated with vomiting is not usually considered as a red flag sign for vomiting in a child.

Red Flag Signs in Pediatric Vomiting:

  • Projectile vomiting (Option A ruled out):
    • Suggests gastric outlet obstruction (e.g., pyloric stenosis in infants).
    • High-risk: Requires imaging (ultrasound for pyloric stenosis).
  • Bilious vomiting (Option B ruled out):
    • Indicates intestinal obstruction (e.g., malrotation with volvulus).
    • Surgical emergency: Needs immediate evaluation (upper GI series).
  • Fever with vomiting (Option C ruled out):
    • Raises concern for infection (e.g., meningitis, UTI, sepsis) or appendicitis.
  • Hematemesis
  • Abdominal distention with tenderness
  • Altered mental state
  • Weight loss / Faiulre to thrive

Key Takeaways:

  • Bilious vomiting = Rule out malrotation (especially in neonates).
  • Projectile vomiting in infants → Pyloric stenosis.
  • Photophobia is a neurological, not gastrointestinal, sign.

questions.text: Molar ratio of sodium and glucose in WHO low osmolarity ORS is?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

WHO Low-Osmolarity ORS Composition:

  • Sodium (Na+): 75 mEq/L
  • Glucose (C6H12O6): 75 mmol/L
  • Molar Ratio (Na+:Glucose): 1:1

Advantages:

  1. Optimal Absorption:
    • 1:1 ratio maximizes sodium-glucose cotransport (SGLT1) in the small intestine.
    • Each glucose molecule transports 2 Na+ ions into enterocytes.
  2. Advantages Over Older ORS:
    • Low osmolarity (245 mOsm/L) reduces risk of osmotic diarrhea.
    • More effective than standard ORS (Na+:Glucose = 1:2) for rehydration.

Full ORS Composition (WHO 2002 Formula):

Incorrect options:

1:2 (Option B): This ratio is used in the Older ORS formula (higher osmolarity).

2:3 (Option C), 2:5 (Option D): Not used in any WHO-approved ORS.

Key Takeaways:

  • 1:1 sodium-glucose ratio is critical for efficient rehydration.
  • Low osmolarity (245 mOsm/L) reduces diarrhea risk.
  • Citrate improves stability in tropical climates.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents with bloody diarrhea, fever, and abdominal cramps for 3 days. Stool culture confirms Shigella infection. Which of the following is contraindicated in the management of this child?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In case of Diarrhoea due to infective causes, Anti-diarrhoeal drugs like Loperamide are contraindicated.

Childhood Dysentery:

  • Definition: Acute bloody diarrhea (often with mucus) + fever, caused by:
    • Bacterial: Shigella (most common), Salmonella, Campylobacter, E. coli (EHEC).
    • Parasitic: Entamoeba histolytica.
  • Key Features:
    • Shigellosis: High fever, tenesmus, severe colitis (risk of hemolytic-uremic syndrome with EHEC).
    • Complications: Dehydration, toxic megacolon, seizures (Shigella).

Management Principles:

  1. Rehydration: Oral/IV fluids.
  2. Antibiotics:
    • Shigella: Ciprofloxacin (Option D ruled out) or Azithromycin (reduces duration).
    • Avoid antibiotics in EHEC (↑ HUS risk).
  3. Antiemetics: Ondansetron (Option B ruled out)
  4. Probiotics (Option C ruled out).

Loperamide:

  • Mechanism: Anti-motility agent (Opioid agonist).
  • Risks in Dysentery:
    • Prolongs pathogen contact with gut mucosa → ↑ toxin absorption.
    • ↑ Risk of Toxic megacolon (especially with Shigella).

questions.text: A 9-month-old child has been passing 10 to 12 loose stools per day for the last 9 days. There is no blood or mucus in stools. There is no dehydration as well. Which is the therapy of choice for such a child?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In this case, where there is no apparent dehydration or dysentry, therapy of choice is ORS with Zn.
  • Diagnosis: Acute watery diarrhea - likely viral, e.g., rotavirus (Option C, D ruled out).
    • No dehydration → No need for IV fluids.
    • No dysentery (blood/mucus) → Antibiotics not required.
  • WHO/ESPID Guidelines for Persistent Diarrhea (>7 days):
    • ORS (Oral Rehydration Solution): Prevents/treats dehydration.
    • Zinc supplementation:
      • Dose: 20 mg/day for 14 days (10 mg/day if <6 months).
      • Benefits: Reduces stool volume/duration, boosts immunity (Option A ruled out).

Management Principles:

  • Continue breastfeeding/formula feeds.
  • Avoid antidiarrheals (e.g., loperamide) in children.
  • Monitor for dehydration (capillary refill, skin turgor, urine output).

Key Takeaways:

  1. ORS + zinc is first-line for acute watery diarrhea (even without dehydration).
  2. Antibiotics are reserved for:
    • Dysentery (blood/mucus).
    • Suspected cholera or Giardia.
  3. Probiotics are optional (low evidence for persistent diarrhea).

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents with severe vomiting and diarrhea for 3 days. On examination, the child has sunken eyes, dry mucous membranes, and delayed capillary refill. Which type of dehydration is considered the most dangerous due to its potential complications?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical history suggests Extreme dehydration. Out of the given options, the most dangerous type of dehydration is Hypernatremic dehydration, due to risk of Neurological Sequelae, Mortality.

Dehydration:

  • Definition: Excessive loss of body water and electrolytes, leading to hypovolemia.
  • Classification on basis of Serum Na+:
    • Isonatremic (Na+ 130-150 mEq/L): Most common type (80% of cases).
    • Hyponatremic (Na+ <130 mEq/L): Often due to excessive water intake or loss of sodium-rich fluids.
    • Hypernatremic (Na+ >150 mEq/L): Results from disproportionate water loss (e.g., diarrhea with inadequate water intake).

Risks associated with Hypernatremic dehydration:

  1. Neurological Risks:
    • Rapid correction can cause cerebral edema (due to osmotic shifts).
    • Slow correction risks cerebral hemorrhage (from brain shrinkage and vessel tearing).
  2. High Mortality/Morbidity:
    • Associated with seizures, coma, and permanent neurological damage (Option A, B ruled out).
  3. Management Challenges:
    • Requires slow, controlled rehydration (over 48-72 hours) to avoid complications.

Key Takeaways:

  • Hypernatremic dehydration carries the highest risk of neurological sequelae.
  • Monitor serum sodium closely during rehydration to avoid complications.
  • Isonatremic dehydration is the most common and easiest to manage.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presents with chronic diarrhea, failure to thrive, and abdominal distension. Anti-tTG IgA antibodies are elevated, and duodenal biopsy reveals Villous atrophy. He is diagnosed with Celiac disease. Which of the following foods should be avoided in his diet?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In case of Celiac disease, Gluten containing foods like Semolina should be avoided.

Celiac Disease:

  • Pathophysiology: Autoimmune disorder triggered by gluten (proteins in wheat, barley, rye) in genetically predisposed individuals (HLA-DQ2/DQ8).
  • Clinical features:
    • Chronic diarrhea
    • Malabsorption
    • Abdominal distention
    • Flatulence
    • Failure to thrive, Weight loss
    • Oral ulcers
    • Dermatitis herpetiformis
  • Hallmark: Villous atrophy + Intraepithelial lymphocytes in the small intestine.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Serology: Elevated anti-tTG IgA (90% sensitivity), IgA Deficiency, anti-EMA IgA.
    • Gold Standard: Duodenal biopsy (Marsh classification).

Dietary Management:

  • Avoid:-
    • Gluten-containing grains: Wheat (semolina, durum), barley, rye.
    • Hidden gluten: Sauces, processed foods.
  • Safe Foods:-
    • Grains: Rice, quinoa, sorghum, millet (Option A, B, D ruled out).
    • Others: Fruits, vegetables, meat, dairy (unless lactose intolerant).
  • Key Takeaways:
    • Gluten-free diet is the only treatment for celiac disease.
    • Monitor for complications: Iron deficiency anemia, osteoporosis.
    • Patient education: Cross-contamination risks (e.g., shared utensils).

questions.text: All of the following statements about Wilson disease are true, except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Wilson's Disease:

Wilson's disease is a metal metabolism disorder characterized by excessive copper deposition in the liver, brain, kidneys, and eyes.

  • Features include hepatic failure or cirrhosis, hemolytic anemia, KF ringsin the eyes, sunflower cataracts, neuropsychiatric manifestations and parkinsonism-like features
  • In CNS, theexcess copper gets deposited into basal ganglia.
  • Pathophysiology:
    • Mutations in ATP7B gene (chromosome 13) → impaired copper excretion → toxic accumulation in liver, brain, and cornea.
    • It is inherited as an Autosomal recessive trait (Option A ruled out).

Clinical findings:

  • Ocular Findings:
    • Kayser-Fleischer rings (Option B ruled out): Copper deposition in Descemet's membrane observed on Slit-lamp examination.
    • Sunflower cataracts (rare).
  • Hepatic Findings:
    • ↑ Hepatic copper (>250 μg/g dry weight) (Option C ruled out).
    • Steatosis, cirrhosis, or acute liver failure.
  • Neurologic/Psychiatric:
    • Tremors, dystonia, dysarthria, psychosis.
  • Laboratory Hallmarks:
    • ↓ Ceruloplasmin (<20 mg/dL).
    • ↑ 24-hour urinary copper (>100 μg/24h).

Ceruloplasmin is low due to:

  • Impaired copper incorporation into apoceruloplasmin.
  • Accelerated degradation of unstable ceruloplasmin.

Management:

  • First-line: Copper chelators (D-penicillamine, trientine).
  • Zinc acetate: Blocks intestinal copper absorption.
  • Liver transplant: For fulminant liver failure.

Key Takeaways:

  • Triad: ↓ Ceruloplasmin + ↑ Urinary copper + KF rings.
  • Screen siblings of affected patients (25% recurrence risk).

questions.text: Dubin-Johnson syndrome (DJS) and Rotor syndrome (RS) can be distinguished by all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Shared Features Between DJS and RS:

  • Conjugated hyperbilirubinemia - both cause similar bilirubin levels, typically 2-5 mg/dL.
  • Benign course with normal liver function.
  • Autosomal recessive inheritance.

Distinguishing Features:

Diagnosis:

  • First-line: Urinary coproporphyrins (gold standard to differentiate).
  • Imaging: Oral cholecystogram (historical; now replaced by MRCP).

Key Takeaways:

  • DJS: Black liver, normal total coproporphyrins (↑ Type I), no gallbladder on imaging.
  • RS: Normal liver, ↑ total coproporphyrins, normal gallbladder.
  • Bilirubin levels overlap → Not useful for differentiation.

questions.text: What is the most common indication for liver transplantation in children?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Biliary atresia accounts for 50-60% of all pediatric liver transplants.
  • Other Indications:
    • Metabolic disorders (e.g., Urea cycle defects, Tyrosinemia).
    • Acute liver failure (e.g., Viral hepatitis, Toxins).
    • Cholestatic diseases (e.g., Alagille syndrome)

Biliary Atresia:

  • Pathology:
    • Progressive Fibro-obliteration of bile ducts → cirrhosis by 6-12 months if untreated.
  • Treatment:
    • Kasai portoenterostomy (initial surgery) fails in ~50% of cases → requires transplant by age 2.
  • Incidence: 1 in 10,000-20,000 live births.

Transplant Outcomes:

  • 1-year survival: >90% (biliary atresia).
  • Living donor grafts often used (parent-to-child).

Key Takeaways:

  • Biliary atresia is the #1 cause of pediatric liver transplants.
  • Kasai procedure delays but often doesn't prevent transplant need.
  • Screen for cardiopulmonary anomalies (associated in 10-15%).

Incorrect options:

Fulminant hepatitis (Option B): Rare in paediatric age group.

Reye's syndrome (Option C): Rare, due to aspirin avoidance.

Wilsons disease (Option D): Treatable with chelators; transplant only for acute liver failure.

choices.text: Genetic defect in secretion of bile into canaliculi

questions.text: A 3-week-old neonate presents with progressive jaundice, hepatomegaly, acholic stools, and elevated direct bilirubin (10 mg/dL). Ultrasound shows non-visualization of the gallbladder. The infant dies of liver failure by 9 months. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given Clinical history suggests a diagnosis of Extrahepatic biliary atresia.

  • Timing: Jaundice beyond 2 weeks (physiologic jaundice resolves by then).
  • Key Findings:
    • Acholic stools - pathognomonic for biliary obstruction.
    • Non-visualized gallbladder on ultrasound (75% sensitive for biliary atresia).
    • Elevated direct bilirubin (>2 mg/dL) + normal glucose/creatinine (rules out metabolic disorders).
  • Liver failure and death by 9 months

Diagnosis:

  • First-line:
    • HIDA scan: No excretion into bowel.
    • Liver biopsy: Bile duct proliferation, portal fibrosis.
  • USG: Triangular 'Chord sign' observed at bifurcation of Portal vein.
  • Gold Standard:
    • Intraoperative cholangiogram - absence of bile ducts observed.

Chord sign:

Management:

  • Kasai portoenterostomy - if done before 60 days of life delays liver failure.
  • Liver transplant ultimately required in >80% of cases.

Incorrect options:

α1-Antitrypsin deficiency (Option A): Is not usually associated with Acholic stools, and is raely fatalin nature.

Mild glucuronosyltransferase deficiency (Gilbert syndrome) (Option B): Presents with Indirect Hyperbilirubinemia.

Genetic defect in secretion of bile into canaliculi (Option C): Seen in Progressive Familial Intrahepatic Cholestasis (PFIC). In such a case, Gall bladder is usually visualised on USG.

Key Takeaways:

  • Acholic stools + direct hyperbilirubinemia = Biliary atresia until proven otherwise.
  • Non-visualized gallbladder on ultrasound is a red flag.
  • Kasai procedure must be performed early (ideally <8 weeks).

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents with acute abdominal pain, vomiting, lethargy, and red-currant jelly stools. Contrast enema is as shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given clinical history and 'Coiled spring' sign on Barium enema points to a classical case of Intussusception

  • Intussusception is the "telescoping" of a segment of proximal bowel (the intussusceptum) into downstream bowel (the intussuscipiens).
  • Most cases occur in infants 1-2 years old; in this age group, nearly all cases are idiopathic.
  • Intussusception may be ileoileal, jejunoileal, or jejunojejunal.
  • Classic Triad:
    1. Colicky abdominal pain (intermittent, severe)
    2. Vomiting (bilious if obstruction progresses)
    3. Red-currant jelly stools (blood + mucus from mucosal ischemia)

Diagnosis:

  • Contrast Enema (Diagnostic and Therapeutic):
    • "Coiled spring" sign: Contrast wraps around the intussusceptum like a spring (pathognomonic).
  • Ultrasound: Target sign - Concentric rings of bowel layers.

Coiled spring sign:

Target sign:

Incidence: Peak age:- 3 months-3 years (90% idiopathic; 10% due to lead point, e.g., Meckel's diverticulum).

Management:

  • Non-operative:
    • Pneumatic/hydrostatic reduction (success rate: 80-90%).
  • Surgical:
    • Required if perforation, peritonitis, or reduction fails.

Incorrect options:

Volvulus (Option A): Presents with sudden bilious vomiting + abdominal distension (no Red-currant stools).

Meckel's diverticulitis (Option C): Causes pain but no coiled spring sign; more common in older children.

Adhesions (Option D): Post-surgical history; no pathognomonic imaging signs.

choices.text: Blood transfusion to maintain Hb >10 g/dL

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presents with acute hematemesis, hemoglobin of 6.2 g/dL, and hemodynamic instability. After fluid resuscitation, which of the following is not indicated prior to endoscopy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In a case of Upper GI bleed, after fluid resuscitation, Hb should be maintained at ≥7 g/dL.

Pre-Endoscopy Management of UGI Bleed.

  • Hemodynamic Stabilization:
    • Fluid resuscitation (NS/RL) to restore perfusion.
    • Blood transfusion (BT):
      • Goal: Maintain Hb ≥7 g/dL.
      • Hb >10 g/dL is excessive (↑ risk of volume overload/rebleeding).
  • Pharmacotherapy:
    • Pantoprazole infusion ( Option B ruled out): PPI infusion reduces rebleeding risk (especially in peptic ulcers).
    • Octreotide ( Option D ruled out): Vasoconstrictor for suspected variceal bleeding (↓ portal pressure).
    • IV Erythromycin (Option C ruled out): Prokinetic to clear gastric blood (improves endoscopic visualization).

Endoscopy should be done within 24 hrs after stabilization.

Key Takeaways:

  • Transfuse only to Hb ≥7 g/dL (unless active cardiac ischemia).
  • PPI + Octreotide are pre-endoscopy cornerstones for ulcers/varices.
  • Erythromycin enhances endoscopic yield.

choices.text: Combination of Polyethylene glycol solution & enema
High fibre diet and follow-up after 3 months

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy passes hard, infrequent stools for the last 2 years. Also, sometimes he soils his underwear. On examination, you found an anal fissure, and his rectum is full of hard stools. All other examinations are normal. Your most likely diagnosis is functional constipation. What is the most effective initial treatment?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The child has now presented with severe constipation with rectal impaction. The 1st step in the treatment of severe constipation is disimpaction, which requires administration of Polyethylene glycol solution (Movicol) (or mineral oil) ± Rectal enema, done stat, followed by maintenance therapy.

Stepwise Management

  1. Disimpaction (First Step):
    • PEG: 1-1.5 g/kg/day for 3-6 days (oral).
    • Enema (if severe): Sodium phosphate or saline enema (1-2 doses).
    • Clears impacted stool before maintenance therapy.
  2. Maintenance Therapy:
    • PEG (maintenance dose):2-0.8 g/kg/day + behavioral modifications.
    • Lactulose or senna (second-line if PEG fails).
  3. Supportive Measures:
    • High-fiber diet (Option B, C, D ruled out)
    • Toilet training: Scheduled sits after meals.

Functional constipation: Fecal impaction:-

questions.text: A 60-hour-old neonate has not passed meconium since birth. Abdominal distension is noted, but there is no bilious vomiting. What is the investigation of choice to evaluate this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The investigation of choice in case of not passing Meconium beyond 48 hours with absence og bilious vomiting, is Contrast enema.

Differential Diagnosis:

  • Hirschsprung disease - most common surgical cause.
  • Meconium plug syndrome - benign, often resolves with enema.
  • Meconium ileus - associated with cystic fibrosis).
  • Anorectal malformations (e.g., imperforate anus).

Hirschsprung Disease (HD):

  • Absence of ganglion cells (Auerbach & Meissner plexuses) in distal bowel leading to functional obstruction.
  • Findings: Transition zone (dilated proximal colon → narrow aganglionic segment).
  • Rectal biopsy (gold standard) is performed if HD is suspected.

Meconium Plug/Ileus:

  • Contrast enema can be both diagnostic and therapeutic (evacuates the meconium plug).

Diagnosis:

  • Clinical Exam:
    • Check for anal patency (rule out imperforate anus).
    • Assess for abdominal distension or bilious vomiting (red flags).
  • Contrast Enema:
    • First-line for suspected HD or meconium obstruction.
  • Rectal Biopsy:
    • Confirms HD (absence of ganglion cells + hypertrophic nerves).

Key Takeaways:

  • Contrast enema is the initial imaging modality for delayed meconium passage.
  • Hirschsprung disease is the most critical diagnosis to exclude.
  • Meconium plug syndrome is a common, treatable cause (contrast enema often curative).

Incorrect options:

Invertogram (Option A): Used for Anorectal malformations (e.g.,Imperforate anus).

USG abdomen (Option B): USG is non-specific in case of Hirschsprung's disease, but is reliable to detect Anorectal malformations,meconeum ileus or plug, but is not preferred over Contrast enema

CT scan (Option C): Not preferred over contrast enema, but can be considered as a confirmatory investigation.
